metadata.case_name: State of Bombay v. S. L. Apte and Another

facts.text: S. L. Apte was Managing Director and Miss Dwarkabai Bhat was Managing Director of Womens department of The Long Life Insurance Company, headquartered at Poona.
Power of attorney executed by the company in favour of first respondent (Apte) in June 1942, vesting him with power, control and possession of company moneys for investment in proper securities.
Second respondent (Bhat) acted under another power of attorney executed in June 1942, assisting first respondent in maintaining company accounts.
Audit conducted in 1952 disclosed considerable sums over Rs. 55,000 shown as cash balances with first respondent.
Further enquiries showed moneys aggregating over Rs. 95,000 withdrawn from time to time by first respondent with assistance and sanction of second respondent, professedly for company expenses.
Voucher dated August 9, 1952, evidencing withdrawal of the amount by first respondent, signed by him and second respondent in token of sanction.
Respondents could not furnish proper account of legitimate expenses for which the amount was purportedly taken.
Both respondents prosecuted for offence under s. 409 IPC and s. 105 Indian Insurance Act in Criminal Case 82 of 1953.
Magistrate convicted and sentenced both respondents for both offences.
Sessions Judge, Poona, by order dated May 3, 1954, affirmed conviction and sentence under s. 409 IPC, set aside conviction under s. 105 Insurance Act due to lack of sanction under s. 107.
Conviction and sentence under s. 409 IPC became final.
Insurance Company obtained sanction of Advocate-General of Bombay under s. 107 and filed complaint on January 18, 1955, against respondents under s. 105 Insurance Act.
Magistrate took case on file and issued process.
Respondents applied on March 22, 1955, to dismiss complaint as barred by s. 403 CrPC due to previous conviction and acquittal on same offence.
Magistrate overruled plea, finding acquittal not on merits but for lack of sanction rendering court without jurisdiction.
Trial proceeded, evidence led, Magistrate acquitted respondents on ground of bar by Art. 20(2) Constitution and s. 26 General Clauses Act.
State of Bombay filed appeal to Bombay High Court under s. 417 CrPC, dismissed, but certificate under Art. 134(1) granted.

Allegations in original complaint (Cr Case 82/1953) similar to those in new complaint under s. 105, but not complete identity; paras 12 and 13 in new complaint allege wrongful obtainment/possession/withholding/application of Rs. 95,000 on Aug 9, 1952.

legal_issues.text: Whether the offences under s. 409 IPC and s. 105 Indian Insurance Act are the same offence, so as to attract the bar of Art. 20(2) Constitution and s. 26 General Clauses Act against second prosecution and punishment.
Whether direction under s. 105 Insurance Act to deliver up or refund property is punishment within Art. 20(2) and s. 26 GCA.

petitioner_arguments.text: Offences under s. 409 IPC and s. 105 Insurance Act are distinct in ingredients: s. 409 requires entrustment/dominion and dishonest intent; s. 105 requires only wrongful obtainment/possession/withholding/application without entrustment or intent.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 20(2) Constitution; s. 26 General Clauses Act; s. 405, 409 IPC; s. 105 Insurance Act

petitioner_arguments.text: Even if allegations similar, identity of offences requires identical ingredients, not just facts alleged.

respondent_arguments.text: Prosecution under s. 105 barred by previous conviction under s. 409 for same offence, invoking Art. 20(2) and s. 26 GCA; also s. 403 CrPC.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 20(2) Constitution; s. 26 General Clauses Act; s. 403 CrPC

court_reasoning.text: To attract Art. 20(2), second prosecution must be for the same offence, i.e., identical offences; even if allegations substantially similar, distinct offences do not invoke ban.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Offences identical only if ingredients same.

court_reasoning.text: s. 409 IPC (aggravated criminal breach of trust u/s 405) requires entrustment/dominion and dishonest intent; s. 105 Insurance Act requires only wrongful obtainment/possession/withholding/application to unauthorised purposes, no entrustment or dishonest intent needed.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Offences distinct in ingredients, content and scope.

court_reasoning.text: s. 26 GCA emphasizes ingredients of offences, not facts alleged; ban applies only if same offence.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Distinct offences, no double punishment bar.

court_reasoning.text: Proceeds on basis that direction to refund under s. 105 is punishment within Art. 20(2) and s. 26, as not contested.
Consistent with s. 403(2) CrPC allowing trial for distinct offence.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Original joint charges justify separate prosecutions.

holdings.text: Offences under s. 409 IPC and s. 105 Indian Insurance Act are distinct; no bar under Art. 20(2) Constitution or s. 26 General Clauses Act to second prosecution and punishment.

precedents_cited.case_name: Om Prakash Gupta v. State of U.P.
precedents_cited.relevance: Offence u/s 409 IPC not identical to s. 5(2) Prevention of Corruption Act due to different ingredients.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Madhya Pradesh v. Veereshwar Rao Agnihotry
precedents_cited.relevance: Acquittal u/s 5(2) Prevention of Corruption Act does not bar conviction u/s 409 IPC as offences not same; Art. 20(2) inapplicable.
Possession and sale of liquor are distinct offences; no double jeopardy for separate steps in transaction.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Art. 20(2) bars prosecution and punishment for same offence more than once; certificate under Art. 134(1) for appeal.

statutes_cited.name: General Clauses Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Offender liable under either enactment but not punished twice for same offence; requires identity of offences.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines criminal breach of trust requiring entrustment and dishonest intent; s. 409 aggravated form.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Insurance Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Punishes wrongful obtainment/withholding/misapplication of insurer property without entrustment/intent; sanction u/s 107 prerequisite.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: s. 403 bars trial for same offence; allows for distinct offence; s. 417 for state appeal against acquittal.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the State's appeal, holding that offences under s. 409 IPC and s. 105 Insurance Act are distinct due to different ingredients, so no bar under Art. 20(2) or s. 26 GCA; reversed High Court and Magistrate's acquittal on s. 105.
outcome.relief_granted: Prosecution under s. 105 permitted to proceed.

key_quotes.text: "No person shall be prosecuted and punished for the same offence more than once."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Text of Art. 20(2) Constitution central to double jeopardy issue.

key_quotes.text: "Where an act or omission constitutes an offence under two or more enactments, then the offender shall be liable to be prosecuted and punished under either or any of those enactments, but shall not be liable to be punished twice for the same offence."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Text of s. 26 General Clauses Act defining double punishment bar.

key_quotes.text: The crucial requirement therefore for attracting the Article is that the offences are the same, i.e., they should be identical.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Court's interpretation of 'same offence' under Art. 20(2).

key_quotes.text: "the offence of criminal misconduct punishable under s. 5(2) of the Prevention of Corruption Act... is not identical in essence, import and content with an offence under s. 409 of the Indian Penal Code"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quote from Om Prakash Gupta affirming distinct offences.
